Suggested questions

  • Would a scale factor or ratio help you find the height? (Yes. Either one could be used.)
  • How is this problem similar to Problem 4.1? (We are finding a missing side of a triangle.)
  • Do your measurements seem reasonable?(Answers will vary.)

When students are working with the mirror method in What If Situation A monitor how they are making their measurements.  Remind them to walk backwards until they see the reflection of the top of the object in the mirror.
When students are working with the shadow method in What If Situation A monitor how they are making their measurements. Assist them with measuring from end to end on the shadow.
What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?
Describe how similar figures can be used to find missing measurements of objects that cannot be measured directly. Is there another method? Explain.
(As you are circulating during the Explore find examples of students using scale factors or ratios to find the heights of the objects.  Use this student work in the summary discussion.)
